snippet: For years, a Michigan inmate gathered evidence he said cast doubt on his murder conviction, but there is no assurance that he will be able to present it in court.
abstract: Adam Liptak Sidebar column on Michigan man Floyd Perkins, serving life sentence for murder but who has always proclaimed his innocence; says Perkins gathered evidence for years that he says cast doubt on his conviction, but even though the Supreme Court has agreed to hear his case, there is no assurance he will be able to present it in court, since prosecutors contend Perkins had missed his deadline.
lead_paragraph: For years, a Michigan inmate gathered evidence he said cast doubt on his murder conviction, but there is no assurance that he will be able to present it in court.

headline.print_headline: Question for Justices: When Does New Evidence Require a New Trial?
headline.seo: Post-Trial Evidence Is Issue in Supreme Court Case
headline.main: Case Asks When New Evidence Means a New Trial
